children.value: The focus of this major-version release is to provide a lighter, nimbler core library as a foundation for future features and improved extensibility.
Many Apollo Server 2 users don't need to make any code changes to upgrade to Apollo Server 3!
This is especially likely if you use the "batteries-included"
require code changes and how to make them. If you encounter issues while migrating, please
For a list of all breaking changes,
Apollo Server 3 supports Node.js 12 and later.
(Apollo Server 2 supports back to Node.js 6.) This includes
all LTS and Current versions at the time of release
If you're using an older version of Node.js, upgrade your runtime before upgrading to Apollo Server 3.
Apollo Server has a peer dependency on
(the core JS GraphQL implementation), which means you are responsible for choosing the version installed in your app.
If you're using an older version of
, upgrade it to a supported version before upgrading to Apollo Server 3.
Apollo Server 2 provides built-in support for subscriptions and file uploads via the
packages, respectively. It also serves GraphQL Playground from its base URL by default.
Apollo Server 3 removes these built-in integrations, in favor of enabling users to provide their own mechanisms for these features.
You can reenable all of these integrations as they exist in Apollo Server 2.
Apollo Server 2 provides limited, built-in support for WebSocket-based GraphQL subscriptions via the
package. This integration doesn't work with Apollo Server's plugin system or Apollo Studio usage reporting.
Apollo Server 3 no longer contains this built-in integration. However, you can still use
for subscriptions if you depend on this implementation. Note that as with Apollo Server 2, this integration won't work with the plugin system or Studio usage reporting.
no longer re-exports all of the exports from the
We hope to add more fully-integrated subscription support to Apollo Server in a future version.
library is no longer maintained. A newer, actively-maintained
package exists. These libraries implement different protocols for GraphQL subscriptions over WebSocket, so you need to adjust your client to support
. This migration guide shows how to reenable
to make your transition from Apollo Server 2 to Apollo Server 3 as easy as possible, but we recommend that you then migrate from
once you've finished the upgrade. The
shows how to use the newer
Currently, these instructions are only for Apollo Server's Express integration. It is likely possible to integrate
with other integrations. PRs to this migration guide are certainly welcome!

Apollo Server 2 provides built-in support for file uploads via an outdated version of the
library. Using an updated version of
requires you to disable this built-in support due to backward incompatible changes.
This built-in support is removed in Apollo Server 3. To use

By default, Apollo Server 2 serves the (now-
IDE from its base URL in non-production environments. In production, it serves no landing page. Apollo Server 2 also accepts a
constructor option to override this default behavior (for example, to enable GraphQL Playground even in production).

Apollo Server 3 removes GraphQL Playground (and its associated constructor option) in favor of a landing page that links to Apollo Sandbox in non-production environments. In production, it serves a simplified landing page instead.
You can customize your Apollo Server 3 landing page, as described in
You can continue to use GraphQL Playground by installing its associated plugin. You customize its behavior by passing options to the plugin instead of via the

option is determined in different ways by different Node.js framework integrations. In many cases, it's necessary to manually specify

anymore. If your Apollo Server 2 app specified
(and you wish to continue using GraphQL Playground), try removing
and see if it works for you.

In Apollo Server 2, fields returning a union type are treated similarly to fields returning a scalar type:
on the type itself is ignored, and

(which itself defaults to 0). In Apollo Server 3, fields returning a union type are treated similarly to fields returning an interface or object type:

. If you were relying on the inheritance behavior, you can specify
explicitly on your union types or union-returning fields, or you can use the new
feature on the union-returning field to restore the Apollo Server 2 behavior. If your schema contained

In Apollo Server 2, most of the logic related to cache control lives in the

and framework integration packages such as

import many symbols from third-party packages and re-export them. This effectively ties the API of Apollo Server to a specific version of those third-party packages and makes it challenging to upgrade to a newer version or for you to upgrade those packages yourself.
In Apollo Server 3, most of these "re-exports" are removed. If you want to use these exports, you should import them directly from their originating package.

In Apollo Server 3, GraphQL Playground is one of several landing pages implemented via plugins, and there are no default options for it. The
for more details on configuring GraphQL Playground in Apollo Server 3.
Several small features have been removed from Apollo Server 3.
Guessing Apollo Studio graph ID from API key
In Apollo Server 2, if you specify an Apollo API key (e.g., with the
, Apollo Server automatically guesses that your Studio graph ID (used for usage reporting, schema reporting, managed federation, and so on) is
In Apollo Server 3, you should instead specify your Studio graph ID explicitly when using features that connect to Studio. You can specify the graph ID by itself in the
, or alongside the variant in a string like
If you set your API key but do
set your graph ref or ID:
If you explicitly set up features like the usage reporting plugin or managed federation, Apollo Server 3 throws an error on startup.
set up or disable the usage reporting plugin
, Apollo Server 3 logs a warning suggesting that you either set your graph ref or disable the usage reporting plugin.

Global TypeScript definitions have been removed from
since they conflicted with similar global types provided by
, which we use in Apollo Server's test suite.  These removed types include types which resemble those of
See the full list prior to removal here

We don't expect this to affect many users and we have not publicly suggested using these types in the past, but it's possible that implementations may be using them inadvertently (e.g., from auto-import on
).  While other type definition sets provide similar hand-curated types, for the time being, we have chosen to rely the same-named types from TypeScript's
.  Even if those types are more appropriate for browsers, they're a reliable and well-maintained source.  For more details, including our plan for adjusting this again in the future,
Almost all plugin events are now async
are synchronous (their return value is not a
), and some are "maybe-asynchronous" (they could return a
if they wanted, but didn't have to). This means that you can't do asynchronous work in the former events, and the typings for the latter events are somewhat complex.
all plugin methods are always asynchronous: they always return a
In practice, this means that all of your plugin events should use
functions or methods. If you are using TypeScript, you need to do this for your code to compile.
In practice, Apollo Server generally uses
on values returned by plugin methods instead of an explicit
s and normal values. If you aren't using TypeScript, you might be able to get away with synchronous plugin methods for the time being.

Bad request errors more consistently return 4xx

In Apollo Server 2, certain poorly formatted requests receive HTTP responses with a 5xx status (indicating a server error) instead of 4xx (indicating a client error). For example, this occurs in some integrations for a missing POST body or a JSON parse error.
In Apollo Server 3, these errors are handled in a more consistent manner across integrations and consistently return HTTP responses with a 4xx status.
constructor either as the third argument,
In other words, these two lines are equivalent with Apollo Server 2:

new ApolloError(message, code, {key: 'value'})
new ApolloError(message, code, {extensions: {key: 'value'}})

In Apollo Server 3, only the first line above is supported. If you try to use the second line, the constructor throws an error. Before upgrading, replace any code using the second form with the first form.

Peer deps instead of direct deps
In Apollo Server 3, these packages have

dependencies on their corresponding framework packages. This means that you need to install a version of that package of your choice yourself in your app (though most likely that was already the case).

In Apollo Server 3, we no longer guarantee future support for

implements parsing AWS Lambda events and performing standard web framework logic inside the package itself. As Lambda added new capabilities, the logic had to adapt, and as Apollo Server added new features, they had to be implemented from scratch in
. Additionally, there was no way to add additional HTTP functionality (e.g., "middleware") to
is implemented as a wrapper around

to parse AWS Lambda events into Express requests. This simplifies the implementation and enables us to support new Lambda integrations such as Application Load Balancers. Additionally, because it now uses Express internally, you can extend HTTP functionality via Express middleware using the new

In Apollo Server 3, the handler returned by

All currently supported Lambda runtimes support async handlers. However, if you are currently wrapping the handler returned from
in your own larger handler and passing a callback into it, this no longer works. Rewrite your outer handler to be an async function and
